June 1918.SECRET.; mi 1 ';:xkW NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION-No. 57.JFee7c ewW 22 w Jwwe, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS.Mines have been laid in the Heligoland Bight, in the North Sea, and in the northern North Sea. approaches to the Dover Straits.On 19th June the light cruiser " Furious " and vessels of the First Light Cruiser Squadron were attacked on two occasions by enemy seaplanes to the westward of Denmark, but were not damaged. One German seaplane was shot down and two prisoners taken. One of our seaplanes flown from the light cruiser " Galatea " is missing, but is presumed to be the machine reported as having landed in Denmark owing to engine trouble and fog.On 20th June an enemy submarine attacked a fishing fleet about 100 miles from Foula Island. The armed fishing boat " Conan Doyle," which was in charge of the fishing section, engaged the submarine, which withdrew without damaging the fishing vessels.On 22nd June the airship N.S. 3, whilst on patrol, came down in the sea six miles from Dunbar. The engines sank and the envelope was wrecked, but five of the crew were rescued by the Destroyer " Moy," the remaining five being drowned.A number of reconnaissances and patrols have been carried out in various areas by R.A.F. machines employed on naval duty.Machines from Dunkirk have, in addition, made the following raids :-Date.June 15-16tHObjective.Approximate weight ofbombs dropped.Flanders area.Results observed or remarks.16th 16-17th17th17-18th18th .21st 22ndLa Brugeoise Works ......Zeebrugge and Bruges CanalBruges Docks............Thourout Railway Junction and'aerodrome............Ostend Docks .........Bruges Docks, Ostend Docks, Zee-brugge, Ghistelles and Aertrycke Bruges Docks, Ostend Docks, Zee-brugge, St. Denis Westrem andMaria Aelter Bruges Docks............Ostend Docks and ZeebruggeLa Brugeoise Works, Maria Aelter Aerodrome, Thourout Railway Junction, Bruges Docks and Os-t end Docks..........Ostend Docks and Bruges Docks ...Zeebrugge .........Bruges Docks, St. Pierre Capelle, Ostend Docks and Mariakerke ... Submarines During the week under review from six to eleven large enemy submarines have been operating. located, one of these being of the converted " Deutschland " type which was still operating off the United States coast. Two other large boats were working to the westward of the English Channel, and the remainder were on passage to their operating areas. The Irish Sea has this week been almost entirely clear of submarines, and there are indications that it is the enemy's intention that their larger submarines should operate further west of the southern approaches to the British Isles than has been their practice during recent months.Actions The following Table shows the number of actions between Allied craft and enemywith enemy submarines which are reported to have taken place in all waters during recent weeks, and the nature of the craft which have been engaged; and also the number of submarines which have been destroyed as the result of such actions: submarines. In the latter area the minelaying has developed into a large operation which the enemy appears anxious to complete, and, from the data' at present available, it is inferred that the object of this large mined area is tactical, as it lies in the vicinity of the route which the Grand Eleet would be likely to follow if proceeding southwards from Scapa. The minesweeping force in this region has been reinforced to the full extent which is at present practicable.The following table shows the number of enemy mines destroyed and British vessels sunk by mine in Home Waters (including the Havre and Cherbourg areas) in recent weeks: Week Ended.Number of Enemy Moored Mines Destroyed.Number of British Mine-sweepers and Patrols Sunk bv Mines.Number of British Merchant Steamships Sunk by Mines.May 11th 18th ,, 25th June 1st ,, 8th 15th 22nd37 50 39 34 48 18 34Nil Nil2Nil Nil111Nil Nil Nil 1Nil NilThe vessel sunk this week is a drifter which was mined in the Lowestoft area. MOVEMENTS OF ENEMY SHIPS.During the week under review five enemy merchant ships arrived at and three sailed Merchant-from Norwegian ports outside the Cattegat. No enemy ships have- entered or left men. Rotterdam.FOREIGN NAVAL INTELLIGENCE. Russia.Allied warships have been officially informed that they must leave the Nor'ih Russian ports, but it is admitted by the Russian authorities that these instructions were given in order to pacify Germany and that it is not expected that they should be carried out.H.M. Government have arranged for the immediate despatch of rations for 48,000 persons (including 23,000 railway employees) in Northern Russia for three months, and the United States Government have been asked, to arrange for the provisioning of Murmansk province after the end of September.One Dreadnought battleship and four destroyers are reported to have returned to Sevastopol from Novorossisk, but there are conflicting reports as to the other Dread-nought battleship and the destroyers which remain at the latter port, one of which is to the effect that lack of personnel prevents their transfer to Sevastopol, and another that they have been blown up by their crews.The British merchant vessels " Wolverton," Thistleton " and " Trevorian " are at Sevastopol, flying the German flag.Spain.Three further cases of Allied merchant vessels being attacked by German submarines in Spanish territorial waters have been reported recently, the victims in each case being sailing ships. Two of these ships were taken outside territorial waters by the crew of a submarine and then sunk by bombs.China.It is officially announced that on June 9th, owing to the disturbed conditions prevailing, Japanese marines were landed at Swatow..Naval Staff,21th June, 1918.[Appendices.
